data:
Make beautiful websites with Next.js & MDX.


Simple, powerful and flexible site generation framework with everything you love from Next.js.


Get started ‚Üí











Full-power documentation in minutes.




Links and images are always optimized.


Nextra automatically converts Markdown links and images to use Next.js Link and Next.js Image when possible. No slow navigation or layout shift.
































Advanced syntax highlighting solution.


Performant and reliable build-time syntax highlighting powered by Shiki.



I18n as easy as creating new files.


Name your page files with locales suffixed, Nextra and Next.js will do the rest for you.









MDX 2 lets you use Components inside Markdown, with huge performance boost since v1.





Dark mode included.




Full-text search, zero-config needed.


Nextra indexes your content automatically at build-time and performs incredibly fast full-text search via FlexSearch.










Organize pages intuitively, with file-system routing from Next.js.



A11y as a top priority.


Nextra respects system options such as Increase Contrast and Reduce Motion.



Hybrid rendering, next generation.


You can leverage the hybrid rendering power from Next.js with your Markdown content including SSG, SSR, and ISR.



And more...


SEO / RTL Layout / Plugable Themes / Built-in Components / Last Git Edit Time / Multi-Docs...A lot of new possibilities to be explored.


Start using Nextra ‚Üí

Showcase

Open source projects powered by Nextra

Nextra was initially created by Vercel members Shu Ding and Paco Coursey in 2020. Since 2021, Yixuan Xu contributed tremendously to the project. In 2022, Dimitri Postolov from The Guild joined the core team to help with the development of 2.0.

data: The Docs Theme includes a couple of built-in components that you can use to better style your documentation:

In Nextra, the site and page structure can be configured via the co-located _meta.json files. In the docs theme, there are some extra options available to customize it further.Those configurations affects the overall layout of the theme, espeically the navigation bar and the sidebar.
Read more about Nextra's _meta.json files here.
data.pages#Pages:
The title and order of a page shown in the sidebar should be configured in the _meta.json file as key-value pairs. For example, if you have the following file structure:











You can define how the pages are shown in the sidebar via the _meta.json file:


If any routes are not listed in the _meta.json file, they will be appended to the end of the sidebar and sorted alphabetically, and the title will be formatted with Title.
data.folders#Folders:
Folders can be configured in the same way as pages. For example:



















The top-level _meta.json file contains the meta information for the top-level pages and folders:

And the nested _meta.json file contains the meta information for pages in the same folder:

This way, information for pages are grouped together in directories. You can move directories around without having to change the _meta.json file.
data.folders-with-index-page#Folders with Ind:
What if I want to have a folder with an index page? We can add a MDX page with the same name and in the same directory as the folder. Let's say we want to add /fruits route in the example above, we can create a fruits.mdx file in pages:





















Then Nextra knows that the fruits key in _meta.json defines a folder with an index page. If you click that folder in the sidebar, it will open the folder and show you the fruits.mdx page at the same time.
data.external-links#External Links:
You can add external links to the sidebar by adding an item with href in _meta.json:

To always open the link in a new tab, enable the "newWindow": true option:


You can use this option to link to relative internal links too.
data.hidden-routes#Hidden Routes:
By default, all MDX routes in the filesystem will be shown on the sidebar. But you can hide a specific pages or folders by using the "display": "hidden" configuration:

The page will still be accessible via the /contact URL, but it will not be shown in the sidebar.
data.sub-docs#Sub Docs:
By defining a top-level page or folder as "type": "page", it will be shown as a special page on the navigation bar, instead of the sidebar. With this feature, you can have multiple "sub docs", and special pages or links such as "Contact Us" that are always visible.For example, you can have 2 docs folders frameworks and fruits in your project:























In your top-level _meta.json file, you can set everything as a page, instead of a normal sidebar item:

And it will look like this:


Live example on StackBlitz ‚Üó (opens in a new tab)
You can also hide links like Home from the navbar with the "display": "hidden" option.
data.menus#Menus:
You can also add menus to the navbar using "type": "menu" and the "items" option:


Live example on StackBlitz ‚Üó (opens in a new tab)
data.links#Links: Same as the External Links option, you can have external links in the navbar too:
data.fallbacks#Fallbacks:
In the Sub Docs example above, we have to define the "type": "page" option for every page. To make it easier, you can use the "*" key to define the fallback configuration for all items in this folder:

They are equivalent where all items have "type": "page" set.
data.separators#Separators:
You can use a "placeholder" item with "type": "separator" to create a separator line between items in the sidebar:


Together with the sidebar.titleComponent theme option, you can customize the look of titles and separator lines in the sidebar.
data.theme-components#Theme Components:
You can configure the theme for each page using the "theme" option. For example, you can disable or enable specific components for specific pages:

This option will be inherited by all child pages if set to a folder.
data.layouts#Layouts: By default, each page has "layout": "default" in their theme config, which is the default behavior.
data.raw-layout#Raw Layout: By default, Nextra renders the MDX content (such as h1, h2, h3 etc.) with themed components, inside a content container. You can use the "raw" layout to let Nextra to not inject any styles to the content:
data.full-layout#Full Layout: You might want to render some page with the full container width and height, but keep all the other styles. You can use the "full" layout to do that:
data.typesetting#Typesetting:
The "typesetting" option controls typesetting details like font features, heading styles and components like li and code. There are "default" and "article" typesettings available in the docs theme.The default one is sutiable for most cases like documentation, but you can use the "article" typesetting to make it look like an elegant article page:

The theme is configured with the theme.config.jsx file. It should export an object that contains your configurations, for example:

Detailed information for each option is listed below.
data.docs-repository#Docs Repository: Set the repository URL of the documentation. It‚Äôs used to generate the ‚ÄúEdit this page‚Äù link and the ‚ÄúFeedback‚Äù link.
data.specify-a-path#Specify a Path:
If the documentation is inside a monorepo, a subfolder, or a different branch of the repository, you can simply set the docsRepositoryBase to the root path of the pages/ folder of your docs. For example:

Then Nextra will automatically generate the correct file path for all pages.
data.seo-options#SEO Options:
You can configure SEO related settings via the useNextSeoProps option. The useNextSeoProps function returns the props that will be passed to the Next SEO component.It is also a hook so you can use APIs like useRouter inside to return values conditionally.

For example, we can have all pages rendering the same suffix for <title>:



The %s is a placeholder that will be replaced by the page title.You can also return it conditionally to avoid adding the suffix to the homepage:
data.head-tags#Head Tags: Configure the <head> tags of the website. You can add meta tags, title, favicon, etc.
data.static-head-tags#Static head tags: If you have only static head tags, it‚Äôs easy to directly put them in head. For example:
data.dynamic-tags-based-on-page#Dynamic tags:
You can also use a function component as head to dynamically generate the head tags based on the current page‚Äôs front matter. For example:

You can refer to the useConfig API section for more information about the useConfig hook and the frontMatter object.
data.dark-mode-and-themes#Dark Mode and Theme: Customize the theme behavior of the website.
data.theme-color#Theme Color:
You can adjust the theme color of the website by setting a primary hue value to dark or light themes.

Try it out for this website:
data.logo#Logo:
The logo of the website rendered on the navbar. It can be a React node or a function component.




Live example on StackBlitz ‚Üó (opens in a new tab)
data.project-link#Project Link:
Show a button that links to your project‚Äôs homepage on the navbar. By default, it links to Nextra‚Äôs GitHub repository.

You can configure project.link and project.icon to customize the project link, for example make it link to your GitLab repository:



If icon is missing, it will be a GitHub icon by default.
data.chat-link#Chat Link:
Show a button that links to your project‚Äôs forum or other social media on the navbar.

You can configure chat.link and chat.icon to customize the chat link, for example make it link to your Twitter account:

If icon is missing, it will be a Discord icon by default.
data.menu-and-custom-links#Menu and Custom Li: Check out Page Configuration to learn how to add custom menus or links to the navbar.
data.banner#Banner: Show a dismissable banner on the top of the website. It can be used to show a warning or a notice.
data.banner-key#Banner key: A banner can be dismissed. By default banner.key will be "nextra-banner" and it‚Äôs used by localStorage to keep the banner state (dismissed or not) on the client.If you have updated your banner content, you should change the key to make sure the banner is shown again. The best practice is to always use a descriptive key for the current content, for example:
data.menu-collapse-level#Menu Collapse Level: By default, the sidebar menu is collapsed at level 2. You can change it by setting sidebar.defaultMenuCollapseLevel to a different number. For example, when set to 0, every folder will be collapsed by default and when set to Infinity, all nested folders will be expanded by default.
data.customize-sidebar-content#Customize side:
Together with the Separators item, you can customize how the sidebar content is rendered by using the sidebar.titleComponent option:


Live example on StackBlitz ‚Üó (opens in a new tab)
data.mdx-components#MDX Components: Provide custom MDX components to render the content. For example, you can use a custom pre component to render code blocks.
data.writing-direction#Writing Direction: The default writing direction of the website.
data.extra-content#Extra Content: Render extra content at the end of the main area of the page. It can be used to render a comment section, a newsletter form, or any other type of content.
data.table-of-contents#Table of Contents: Show a table of contents on the right side of the page. It‚Äôs useful for navigating between headings.
data.floating-toc#Floating TOC: toc.float is enabled by default. When enabled, the TOC will be displayed on the right side of the page and it will be sticky when scrolling. If it‚Äôs disabled, the TOC will be displayed directly on the page sidebar.
data.edit-link#Edit Link: Show an ‚ÄúEdit this page‚Äù link on the page that points to the file URL on GitHub (or other places).
data.feedback-link#Feedback Link:
The built-in feedback link provides a way for users to submit feedback about the documentation. By default, it‚Äôs a link that points to the issue creation form of the docs repository, with the current website title prefilled: example.

To disable it, you can set feedback.content to undefined.
data.navigation#Navigation:
Show previous and next page links on the bottom of the content. It‚Äôs useful for navigating between pages.





The above is also equivalent to navigation: true.
data.last-updated-date#Last Updated Date: Show the last updated date of each page. It‚Äôs useful for showing the freshness of the content.
data.footer#Footer: The footer area of the website. You can either specify some content for the default footer, or fully customize it with a custom component.
data.copyright-information#Copyright informat: You can add some simple content, such as copyright information to the default footer:
data.favicon-glyph-experimental#Favicon Glyph: This isn‚Äôt supported by all browsers, but it‚Äôs a nice way to customize the favicon of the website simply by using an emoji or character.

Nextra first collects all your Markdown files and configurations from the pages directory, and then generates the ‚Äúpage map information‚Äù of your entire site, to render things such as the navigation bar and sidebar below:

data.default-behavior#Default Behavior:
By default, the page map contains all .md and .mdx filenames and the directory structure, sorted alphabetically.
Then, Nextra will use the title package to get formatted page names from filenames.For example if you have the following structure:

The resolved page map will be (note that all names were sorted alphabetically):

And the global page map will be bundled to each page by Nextra. Then, configured theme will render the actual UI with that page map.
data._metajson#_meta.json:
It‚Äôs very common to customize each page‚Äôs title, rather than just using the filename. For example it doesn‚Äôt make sense to have a page titled ‚ÄúIndex‚Äù, but instead have a page titled ‚ÄúHome‚Äù.That‚Äôs where _meta.json comes in. You can have an _meta.json file in each directory, and it will be used to override the default configuration of each page:

And you can put this in your pages/_meta.json file:

It tells Nextra the order of each page, and the correct title. Alternatively, you can do it with title and have other configurations in there as well:

The extra configurations are passed to the theme as additional information. Check the corresponding pages for more information:

data.unexpected-result#Unexpected Result:
Table looks different compared to GFM syntax table:
only children of table body <tbody />{:jsx} is styled
table header is unstyled
table doesn't have margin top
data.why-this-happens#Why This Happens:
MDX2 doesn't replace literal HTML elements with <MDXProvider />{:jsx}.Adam Wathan, creator of Tailwind CSS submitted an issue in MDX2 to have some
an escape hatch that we can name like:
please only transform markdown tags, not literal HTML tags
Table header looks unstyled since not replaced with Nextra's MDX components <tr />{:jsx}, <th />{:jsx} and <td />{:jsx},
for the same reason <table />{:jsx} literal is not replaced and doesn't have default margin-top aka mt-6.
data.one-time-fix#One-Time Fix: Just wrap your table with curly braces { and }, e.g.
data.changing-default-behaviour#Changing Defa:
If this thing is still confusing for you, and you want to use regular literal HTML elements for your tables, do the following:
Install remark-mdx-disable-explicit-jsx package




Setup plugin in nextra function inside next.config.mjs file
